item.title: Tim Hollo
item.description: I'm finding it a little hard to work today with this in my head.Antarctic ice extent is now 6.4 standard deviations below the mean. That is, I'm reliably told, a one in 13 billion year event.We're about to see a lot of shit hit a lot of fans. And we are far from ready.Business as usual is over. Politics as usual is over. We need to be putting our effort into building systems that can help us survive what greed and power and wilful blindness have wrought.#ClimateCrisis #Antarctica

item.title: Jonny
item.description: @computingnature hell ya!!!! i was just checking in on some torrent clients i have seeding some data on academictorrents and several of them had thousands of uploads just from my client - and they weren't even my data! people do really be reusing this data. Now if only we could burn down this publishing system so that labor could be valued how it should be <3

item.title: Robert Sanscartier
item.description: DETROIT ‚Äì Seven major automakers say they're joining forces to build a North American electric vehicle charging network that would rival Tesla's and nearly double the number of fast-charging plugs in the U.S. and CanadaGeneral Motors, BMW, Honda, Hyundai, Kia, Mercedes and Stellantis said Wednesday that they will share in a multibillion-dollar investment to build ‚Äúhigh power‚Äù charging stations with at least 30,000 plugs in urban areas and along travel corridors by 2030https://www.local10.com/business/2023/07/26/major-automakers-unite-to-build-electric-vehicle-charging-network-they-say-will-rival-teslas/

item.title: David Colquhoun

item.description: any Mac M1/M2 silicon #python users here who use #pyqt ? I'm wondering if pyqt6 can be installed with pip on a Mac M1/M2 or if we should recommend conda in our installation instructions. thanks for the help! #pyqtgraph #pyqt #gui (also bothering @jni, maybe you know the answer to this? we're using qtpy so in theory any qt could be used)

item.title: Albert Cardona
item.description: @computingnatureIndeed, the moment data is out there in an accessible format, it will be downloaded, and a lot. Undergrads doing a class project or simply exploring, corporate employees working on their 20% projects, PhD students for whom the data can save them years of work or open up entirely new research directions, PIs writing grants and in need of preliminary data. That‚Äôs the point of opening up data: to serve as the basis for further research, in the best scientific tradition. Data kept under wraps might as well not exist.#academia #openaccess

item.title: Carl Zimmer
item.description: Parabiosis--joining an old mouse's blood vessels to a young one's--can reset the aging clock and extend its lifespan, a new study suggests. Here's my story: https://www.nytimes.com/2023/07/27/health/mice-blood-aging.html

item.title: Prof Christina Pagel
item.description: Hospital admissions with (recorded) Covid increased by 10% over the last week, so continuing the recent increases. But increase is slow week on week and daily admissions are still far below where there were even this spring (and it's not just explained by less testing) 1/3

item.title: Wonder of Science
item.description:
The amazing golden color of these scarab beetles (Chrysina resplendens) is not a result of pigmentation or actual metal, but ‚âà70 microscropic chitin layers of decreasing thickness that reflect light to produce a metallic effect.Video credit: insecthaus_adi/ig
Source: https://www.instagram.com/p/BVaHvmIhjbb/Further reading: https://www.eurekalert.org/news-releases/882153

item.title: Karthik Srinivasan
item.description:
For those who might not know, following a week after the Russia-Ukraine wheat embargo, there are even bigger and ominous signs hinting at global food insecurity and the catastrophic agricultural crises coming our way. India last week banned export on all non-basmati rice varieties. I repeat: EXPORT BAN ON ALL non-basmati RICE varieties.[Aside: export of basmati variety will continue, the demand for which is relatively small in India when compared to the nearly 15 major varieties of rice (it's home to at least a 1000 varieties) consumed by very large populations everyday(these are the ones which are now banned). Basmati is a "festive" and only occasionally consumed variety in India. It is largely exported to the richer nations, many of whom think it is the only variety of rice from India.]Why is India banning rice now?
Answer: global warming.What‚Äôs happening in India (and South Asia at large) should both terrify you and wake you upHere‚Äôs more (facts? trivia? bothersome news? how the world actually works?). 1/9#GlobalWarming #PoliticalEconomy #ClimateChange #FoodSecurity #RiceBan #India #SouthAsia #SubContinent #Agriculture #Food #AgriculturalCrises #Inequality #EcologicalCrises

item.title: Bread and Circuses
item.description:
A beautiful, sad, and justifiably angry essay from Jessica Wildfire (@jessicawildfire) about people continuing to ignore the climate crisis...
___________________________Today I watched a math professor and climate activist named Eliot Jacobson talk to CNN about global temperature records and arctic sea ice. He sums it up in the simplest terms. Climate scientists are shocked at what‚Äôs happening. None of their models predicted any of this. A mass extinction usually takes millions of years. As he said, ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre going to do it in a hundred.‚ÄùFor Jacobson, the collapse of global industrial civilization has become a certainty. A recent column in The Guardian says the same. We‚Äôre already breaking through the 1.5C limit set by the Paris Climate Agreement. Scientists are telling us to brace for 2C or even 3C of warming. All of the books I‚Äôve read make it very clear: That kind of warming will turn the planet into something humans have never seen. Large parts of the earth will become uninhabitable for us.Even the gloomiest climate scientists are left speechless by the disasters unfolding this summer. Climate activists who‚Äôve been urging for an emergency declaration are saying: ‚ÄúI thought we had more time.‚ÄùThe scenarios scientists were predicting for 2050 are happening now, and they don‚Äôt know how much worse it‚Äôs going to get. They‚Äôre starting to admit, they can‚Äôt predict anything anymore.It‚Äôs hard to plan for a future when not even the climate scientists know what‚Äôs going to happen next.Best not to think about it, right?Nobody wants to talk about reality. They want to talk about Barbenheimer. They want to pretend we‚Äôve still got time. If you face the truth of what‚Äôs happening, then suddenly the vast majority of what we‚Äôre forced to do makes no sense anymore.Maybe that‚Äôs why people get so angry now when we talk about climate change. They know, but they want to spend however long they‚Äôve got left chasing and consuming whatever pleasure they can. Part of them knows their time is growing short, and they don‚Äôt want to spend it angry or depressed, or even trying to stop it.When you understand the full scope and gravity of what‚Äôs happening, most jobs don‚Äôt make any sense. It doesn‚Äôt make sense to plan a vacation when half the world is burning. It doesn‚Äôt make sense to save up money to send your kid to college in ten years.But it‚Äôs easier to ignore it all.It‚Äôs easier to keep working and going to movies while you wait for the wildfire, the flood, or the heat wave that kills you. It‚Äôs easier to delay the realization of your climate death as long as possible.
___________________________FULL ESSAY -- https://archive.li/hGjWt#selection-327.0-327.16#Environment #Climate #ClimateChange #ClimateCrisis #ClimateEmergency

item.title: Amber Griffiths
item.description: Seeing a lot of 'omg we're screwed' on here. Yes, but how screwed is still at least partly up to us. A rise of 3C is better than 4C, which is better than 8C. Also seeing a lot of folks telling each other there's no point changing their actions because it's all the big corporations' fault - kinda, but we're their customers, and we also love to copy each other, so one person making a change and talking about it can mean another three people doing so, which cascades. Also feels better to do stuff.
